posts.cooked:
I think everybody in the EU should know this. We have never been that close to mass surveillance via smartphone before. This law must not be introduced!

Patrick Breyer

Chat Control

The End of the Privacy of Digital Correspondence The EU wants to oblige providers to search all private chats, messages, and emails automatically for suspicious content - generally and indiscriminately. The stated aim: To prosecute child...

Please write to your representatives in the EU parliament.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Violent/sexual criminals are such a miniscule percentage of society but law-abiding citizens still get screwed in the name of maybe catching them.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: And who are you catching? Mostly people who reshare content they didn‚Äôt make. It‚Äôs like killing all mosquitos to get rid of malaria.

So, write to your representatives if you are from the EU.

But, btw: Non-EU-citizens would also be involved, of course. If I write to somebody in the US or receive a message from this person, the messages would be scanned either way.

It‚Äôs a huge piece of shit that must be stopped!!!

this is probably the front door, but what do you do with backdoors, which are actually more dangerous:

heise online

Beim Digital Services Act, dem Gesetzesvorhaben der EU zur Regulierung von Online-Plattformen, gehen die gef√§hrlichsten Vorschl√§ge vom Europaparlament aus.

and this initiative comes from the ‚Äúparliament‚Äù itself.

Probably it is more useful to protest against ‚Ä¶ ah, I take this opportunity:
Thank you Apple

posts.cooked:
anon88132:

and this initiative comes from the ‚Äúparliament‚Äù itself.

Which is no wonder regarding the parliament‚Äôs structure! Unfortunately S&D are a reason to be concerned in the meantime!

Screenshot_2021-11-16_18-06-57506√ó721 51.4 KB

Avitus:

a miniscule percentage of society but law-abiding citizens still get screwed

Every govt advertises its own incompetence but people don‚Äôt think rationally and submit to these rules. It keeps happening again and again and in many different countries. Seems to be a universal human trait.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Just need to look at post-9/11 security in the U.S. for how (in)effective monitoring everyone all the time really is. The vast majority of terrorist attacks in the U.S. since 9/11 have been perpetrated by citizens, not foreign nationals.
TSA is probably the most useless part of it. The only good thing in US is that the laws have some expiration timer. Maybe someday they will actually let it expire.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
The TSA is like that scene from ‚ÄúThe Dark Knight‚Äù where the Joker burns a pile of money.

These laws will never expire unless bribing politicians becomes illegal.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Any groups we could join to plan protests against this new proposal? Freedom of speech in private should be a human right in my views. I want the world to consider the importance of it

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Typically they do not have expiry dates

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: And if they do, they get renewed in a worse form (like the Patriot Act), more often than not.
I wasn‚Äôt talking about every law but these surveillance related laws. What Avitus wrote also seems to be correct, so maybe the expiration isn‚Äôt working out so well.

Mails to the EU commission would make sense:
